video.title: The EA Spouse Incident | Fully Ramblomatic

captions.text:
There&#39;s a rather disturbing trend 
with triple-A game studios lately:

Make one bad game. Get shut down. Take too long to 
make a good game. Get shut down. Make and release

several good games that win universal acclaim and 
success. Get shut down. Ask not to be shut down.

Begin an equitable conversation between levels 
of management on the most mutually beneficial

way forward. Then get shut down. A reasonable 
person might think the industry&#39;s a bit fuuucked;

late-stage capitalism has slid into it all the 
way up to the balls. And maybe it&#39;s about time

we started becoming very unreasonable people. &quot;But 
I&#39;m just one reasonable person, Yahtz,&quot; I hear you

cry. &quot;What the hell am I supposed to do about it? 
Urinate on the front step of the Warner Bros. head

office?&quot; Why don&#39;t you join me in my chamber 
of horrors for another episode of—er—I mean,

for this debut episode of a completely new, 
occasional series in Fully Ramblomatic on the

most notorious moments in gaming history, 
and let me tell you a little story about

something one person was able to do. Without 
having to urinate on anything that we know of.

In the late &#39;90s and early 2000s, corporations 
were being shit, and everything was getting worse.

So, usual stuff, really. Video games, while still 
a young, dynamic industry, was old enough to be

attracting a second generation of workers who&#39;d 
played video games as kids and were all like,

&quot;Man, I love blowing the faces off hell imps 
in Doom; I&#39;d love it if it was my job to make

their faces blow off. That&#39;d be much healthier 
than my other plan to initiate a school shooting

massacre.&quot; Video games were exciting. The 
industry had been birthed from scratch by a

veritable pantheon of passionate, visionary, 
big-name creators competing to show the most

dedication to the craft. And being so driven 
and not physically old enough that overworking

themselves would leave them bedridden with their 
spines bent at right angles, there was a certain

cachet attached to working hard. They&#39;d brag of 
doing 12-hour shifts and only sleeping four hours

&#39;cause they were kept awake thinking of all 
the red pixels they were going to put on the

hell imp&#39;s death sprite in the morning. And the 
sharks of corporatism were circling, attracted by

two of its favorite smells: exploitable people and 
absolute distended rectumloads of cash to be made.

Fast forward to 2004, and video game professional 
Erin Hoffman is concerned about her fiancé,

Leander Hasty, who was coming home from 
his job at Electronic Arts every night

and melting into an oleaginous slurry on the 
floor. And after a while, Erin was all like,

&quot;Hang on, I&#39;m pretty sure people aren&#39;t 
supposed to melt into oleaginous slurries;

I think things might be a bit fuuucked.&quot; So, she 
took to LiveJournal to anonymously write what

would become known as the &quot;EA Spouse&quot; blog post. 
You&#39;ll be astonished to learn that her post is,

to this day, still up on Livejournal.com, right 
after you get over your initial astonishment that

LiveJournal is still up on Livejournal.com, and 
you can read for yourself as Erin whistleblows

just how fuuucked labor practices had 
gotten at EA. She recounts that Leander

and employees like him were being forced 
to work 12-hour shifts seven days a week;

that the company had loaded everyone&#39;s testicles 
into a vice and was taking the phrase &quot;crunch

time&quot; just a little too literally. And no one was 
getting paid overtime. When pressed, the company

kept bringing up that overtime law specifically 
exempts computer professionals in California.

I&#39;ve no idea why. Maybe there&#39;s some archaic 
notion that it doesn&#39;t count as work if you

get to sit on your bum, pressing buttons all 
day. It really was mindless corporate evil

beyond all rational sense. The fucking janitor 
could&#39;ve pointed out that a melted oleaginous

slurry wasn&#39;t going to be able to code terribly 
efficiently, on top of being a pain in the arse

to get out of the carpet, but no, the rockstar 
video game bros that built the industry out of

their garages had foregone rest and mental 
health to pursue their passion, and so that

was now the expectation. If you couldn&#39;t hack it, 
making video games was ostensibly a dream job;

they could always reap another harvest of 
starry-eyed STEM grads and wring the life

out of them instead. Standard practice was 
to dazzle new employees with perks—free food,

free ice cream, in-house swimming pools and spas 
that no one would actually have the time to bloody

use—and it was one of these that had been the last 
straw for Erin, according to an interview in the

LA Times. In lieu of providing fair pay or days 
off, EA had elected to boost morale by paying to

send apology bouquets to every employee&#39;s wife. 
And that, incidentally, was the one detail that

made me want to do this video, because until 
that, I wasn&#39;t sure this story had a funny side.

So, what good did one single voice do? Well, 
Erin&#39;s story spread like wildfire. Supportive

messages and similar stories came in from 
all over the industry. All it took to make

the initial crack was one angry woman shining a 
light on the shit everyone had come to accept,

and soon, the whole crème brûlée came 
apart. Three class action lawsuits

ended with Hasty and his colleagues 
receiving a $15 million settlement,

and the industry at large was forced to reclassify 
its employees to make them eligible for overtime,

much like when the Grinch&#39;s heart grew three 
sizes, except against his will, held down,

and his heart forcibly inflated with a bicycle 
pump. Erin herself went on to found Gamewatch,

an independent watchdog organization that 
to this day works tirelessly—oh, actually,

it shut down in 2012. Well, the point is, the 
corporate industry learned its lesson and was

never evil again—oh. That&#39;s not true either. 
Seems like these days, the tech industry doesn&#39;t

work you to death, it just fires you before it&#39;s 
even had the chance. So, ultimately, things never

stopped being fuuucked. I did say it was tough 
to find a funny side. Let&#39;s just giggle at the

bouquet thing again. Christ. In terms of soulless 
machines putting up facades of humanity, that&#39;s

right up there with the prototype rubber-skin 
Terminators Skynet stopped using on day two.

We live in troubling times here in 2025, 
as someone invested in both the video

game industry and the continued existence of 
human civilization. But I find it a comfort to

read stories like these in which we learn that 
things have always been fuuucked, but somehow,

humanity muddles through. America&#39;s had 
terrible, demented presidents before.

Trump is an evolved form of Reagan, with 
the position on Russia reversed and with

all those drugs he kept telling us to say no 
to stuffed up his fucking nose. I suppose the

lesson worth taking is to keep in mind that 
time is always moving forward, that even the

most seemingly indelible of horrors must change 
eventually, and I leave you on one last point to

illustrate that. If you go to Erin Hoffman&#39;s 
LiveJournal, you&#39;ll find a follow-up post to

the EA Spouse story in which Erin muses on the 
impact she has had with the following sentiment:

&quot;Truly, the power of the Internet 
is astounding [...] we live in a

positive age when so much information 
can be shared so easily and quickly.&quot;

And my God, what an innocent time. Considering 
the last 20 years of impact the internet has had,

that statement will be remembered 
by historians alongside Neville

Chamberlain in 1938 waving his 
piece of paper and saying what a

reasonable and level-headed feller 
that Hitler guy turned out to be.
